comment:
Classes are interesting and he explains material thoroughly. Two exams (50%) Final (30%) Homework/“pop” quizzes (20%).
Pop quizzes are easy he gives you a few days heads up. Exams are much more difficult and require a lot of knowledge from textbook and full understanding of all problem sets. I only wish he gave more practice problems/ study guides.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy

comment: The class is difficult but he does a pretty solid job explaining the concepts. You will have to study on your own tho. Attendance isn't mandatory but there are pop quizzes. Tests are large part of the grade, is clear about what's mostly on the exam, but can be some surprises. Don't listen to those that didn't put in the time and got a bad grade.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The material is difficult in general. He's extremely passionate about statistics which makes class tolerable. He's brilliant and will explain several times to help but you have to stop him and ask him as he goes very fast. You'll learn a lot but this is not an easy A.

There is no option for his Econ 4750 Multivariate Data Analysis class. This review is for 4750. This is an Econ-based coding class, and I learned more from this class than 90% of my others. There are 10 problem sets and 2 tests worth 80% of your grade. The first test is relatively easy but the second very challenging. Great professor for 4750.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He's extremely intelligent, and extremely nice. Takes some classes to get used to him but he is as straightforward as can be, lectures every day and tests are a huge chunk. You HAVE to show up. If you try hard and show initiative, he will take care of you. This is NOT a "study for an hour and get a B" course, you must work hard and will learn alot.
You won’t be able to understand anything he says so you’ll be teaching yourself.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Great guy! The material is hard itself, not his fault, so please stop giving him bad reviews because you got a bad grade haha.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: The material is already going to be hard itself so that's not his fault, but there is some extra difficulty with the exams. Two tests and a final are 80% of your grade, and some of the problem solving sections are going to be mentioned in class but not always practiced, so you need to understand and be prepared to work formulas you haven't tried.
rating_tags: Test heavy--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Huang makes his econometrics course very challenging, but makes it clear at the beginning of the semester that "if you work really hard, you will do well." This is reflected in his grading scheme. When I took the course, you needed a 80% to make an A. There is a group project which you will learn a lot of great econometric techniques from.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: The class wasn't too difficult, and the way he structured the attendance policy was actually very sensible (basically you have to show up half of the time). As long as you can deal with some tricky multiple choice and a little bit of algebra, you should be fine.

This class is hard enough and the professor doesn't know how to teach. I'm not trying to blame on his accent but it's pretty bad that I hardly pay attention to his lecture. It's like he's giving a himself a lecture. There's a few students still doing well in the class but their amount of work toward this class is massive.

Dr. Huang is a great professor. His tests are very hard, and he expects a lot from his students. But he sets the benchmark for an A at an 80, so making a good grade is very manageable. If you want to learn, take his class. If you just care about sliding through college without a challenge, take something else.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: I took his Econometrics course over the Fall semester. He is absolutely a horrible professor. Teaching and communication lack skills that are expected out of a college professor. Homeworks, exams and project are not correlated to each other at all. Over 60% of the class failed his course. He offers no curve or help of any sort.

I took this class over the summer and it was extremely difficult. I noticed he only teaches upper level courses, so he should not be teaching intro level courses. His tests were beyond difficult. I barely got a C--would not recommend.
He is very hard to understand, his test are extremely hard.  The stuff we go over is not on the test.  I probably studied for 6 hours a week and still made an F on the test.
Not much learning goes on in the classroom. Nice guy, poor professor. Avoid if you are not an econ whiz.

Very smart professor. You will learn a lot from him. 3 exams were the only things that were graded (final included). The final is not cumulative and he does not curve. A= 85% or above, B= 75% <85%, C= 65% <75% and so on.

Huang is a good professor who knows a good bit about Econ, but he can be difficult to understand. I would definitely read the chapters before the class, it makes it much easier to understand him. He really wants his students to learn and and he challenges you to do so. If you put forth effort, hes a good teacher.

Great teacher who knows a good deal about this subject. His accent is a little difficult to understand and his tests do make you think and comprehend the knowledge well, but if you want to learn it, don't see how that could be a bad thing.

One of the hardest classes I've ever have at KSU.The amount of workload for a summer section is extremely heavy.Exams are hard. If want to do well,you must study really hard,pay closed attention during the class period,and make good notes.  Homework,pop quiz,project,presentation are all required and graded. 80 or up is A but never think that's easy

Huang doesn't know anything about teaching. Its really hard to understand him and not only because of the difficulty of the subject but because of his pronunciation. He doesn't use the book, just his power points. Exams are very hard, expect some "True/False and Explain" And he does not give you any formulas you need to know everything for the exam
Heavy accent - hard to comprehend.  Doing the assigned problems will help come test time.  Bring lots of coffee - you'll need it to stay awake during his lectures.

He is a good professor and will go to any length necessary to expain.  HIs accent can be hard to understand at times.  The class is overall fairly easy, although his tests can be quite challenging.  He curves the entire classes grade at the end of the semester.

Horrible teacher who constantly changes his mind on grading policies.  Professor also gets lost in his own math, which is incorrect for the most part.  If you enjoy teaching yourself, take this class.
